content:
Suppose I have a category CCC with

  • an orthogonal factorisation system (E,M)(E, M)(E,M), where
  • every object ccc is equipped with a colimit cone γc\gamma_cγc​ that presents it;

for example, CCC could be a presheaf topos with the epi-mono factorisation system and the canonical presentation of presheaves as colimits of representables.

Given any morphism f:c→df: c \to df:c→d, it seems to me that, in this situation, I can obtain a factorisation of fff relative to the presentation of ccc, whose second leg is “locally MMM”, in the following way:
1. Take the cone f∘γcf \circ \gamma_cf∘γc​ over ddd, and factorise each component (at some index jjj) into mj∘ejm_j \circ e_jmj​∘ej​

1. By functoriality of the factorisation, j↦cod(ej)=dom(mj)j \mapsto \mathrm{cod}(e_j) = \mathrm{dom}(m_j)j↦cod(ej​)=dom(mj​) extends to a diagram, whose shape is the same as the shape of γc\gamma_cγc​: let f∗(c)f_*(c)f∗​(c) be the colimit of this diagram, presented by the cone η\etaη.

1. We get a morphism f~:c→f∗(c)\tilde{f}: c \to f_*(c)f~​:c→f∗​(c) by universality of γc\gamma_cγc​ considering the cone j↦η(j)∘ejj \mapsto \eta(j)\circ e_jj↦η(j)∘ej​, and a morphism fl:f∗(c)→df_l: f_*(c) \to dfl​:f∗​(c)→d by universality of η\etaη considering the cone j↦mjj \mapsto m_jj↦mj​
1. We have f=fl∘f~f = f_l \circ \tilde{f}f=fl​∘f~​.
Question is: Have you seen this before? Does it have a name? Does it have nice properties e.g. in the presheaf topos case?

One concrete example: take CCC to be the presheaf category of reflexive graphs. Then I believe that, for any morphism fff,

  • f~\tilde{f}f~​ will be a morphism that can identify adjacent vertices & also “contract edges”, but cannot identify non-adjacent vertices or non-contracted pairs of edges;
  • flf_lfl​ will only identify non-adjacent vertices and other pairs of edges.
To give my intuitive understanding of this: f∗(c)f_*(c)f∗​(c) is constructed by “gluing the images through fff of the representables in ccc, exactly in the way that they are glued together in ccc”

Hm, it seems like this wouldn't generally yield an EM factorization system since you could repeat the process on flf_lfl​ (there's no guarantee that the cone η\etaη is the canonical one for f∗(c)f_*(c)f∗​(c))...

Yes, I would not expect that to work in general.

Perhaps I should add that, in the particular example that I am interested into,

  • the canonical cone is from a diagram of “atomic” objects, but also
  • the image of an atomic object through any morphism is an atomic object,

so in fact f∗(c)f_*(c)f∗​(c) is, while not literally the canonical cone, in a certain sense 'equivalent' to it (sorry for the vagueness but I'm still figuring this stuff out); and in this case the factorisation does seem to be functorial.

But meanwhile, I would be also just happy to have some understanding of how to characterise the “first leg” morphisms of this factorisation. In the example I care about the second leg is really characterised by being “locally MMM”, and that fits my intuition about the general construction, but I don't have a good understanding of what the first leg is. It seems like it should belong to EEE in any realistic case, but beyond that I don't know.

Just as an update.
I have focussed on the case that I was originally interested into, which is the category of posets and closed (i.e. lower set-preserving) order-preserving maps, where each poset PPP is “canonically” presented as the colimit of the PPP-shaped diagram of embeddings of lower sets of its elements. The OFS is just epi-mono, which in this case is (surjective closed order-preserving map, closed embedding).

In that case, it turns out that this does produce another interesting orthogonal factorisation system:

  • the right class is the local embeddings, that is, maps that restrict to closed embeddings on each lower set;
  • the left class is maps that for now I've called upward-connected, which are maps that are surjective and satisfy the following property: if f(x)≤f(y)f(x) \leq f(y)f(x)≤f(y), then there exists a zig-zag x≤x1≥x2≤…≥xm≤yx \leq x_1 \geq x_2 \leq \ldots \geq x_m \leq yx≤x1​≥x2​≤…≥xm​≤y such that f(x)≤f(xi)f(x) \leq f(x_i)f(x)≤f(xi​) for all iii.
The middle object arising from the factorisation of f:P→Qf: P \to Qf:P→Q is the colimit of the PPP-shaped diagram of images through fff of the lower sets of elements of PPP.
I'd be curious to know both if this OFS is known, and if it has any interesting version for categories instead of posets!

The obvious generalisation of the right class would be functors F:C→DF: C \to DF:C→D which induce equivalences C/x→D/FxC/x \to D/FxC/x→D/Fx on each slice; the obvious generalisation of the middle-object is the Grothendieck construction of the functor C→CatC \to \textbf{Cat}C→Cat sending xxx to D/FxD/FxD/Fx; not sure what the characterising property of the left class becomes, nor what the "correct" generalisation of closed maps is -- is it full & essentially surjective, or only essentially surjective on all slices?
Yes, must be! Discrete fibrations between posets are precisely the local embeddings
And I think I can roughly see how upward-connected is equivalent to "final" when a map is also closed...
